tn.text: See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]]
Part One of the book begins in 1:2.
"The Best Song" or "The Most Excellent Song"
"which is about Solomon" or "which Solomon composed"
"The oils that you put on your body"
"smell wonderful"

tn.ref: your name is like flowing perfume
tn.text: The woman realizes that her lover has a good reputation. AT: "your name is wonderful like the smell of oil that someone has poured out." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"Bring me along with you." The word "you" refers to the lover.
The word "we" refers to the young woman together with her lover.
"because of you"
"let me praise"

tn.ref: It is natural for the other women to adore you
tn.text: "All who love you are right"
"My skin is dark, but I am still beautiful"

tn.ref: dark like the tents of Kedar
tn.text: The nomadic tribes in Kedar used black goat skins to build their homes. The woman is comparing her skin to these tents. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: lovely like the curtains of Solomon
tn.text: She compares her skin to the beautiful curtains Solomon produced either for his own palace or for the Temple. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
"burned"
"My half-brothers." These brothers probably had the same mother as the woman but not the same father.
"the person who took care of the vineyards"

tn.ref: but my own vineyard I have not kept
tn.text: The woman compares herself to a vineyard. AT: "but I have not been able to take care of myself." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"graze your flocks"
"have your flock lie down"

tn.ref: Why should I be like someone who wanders beside the flocks of your companions?
tn.text: AT: "Tell me so that I will not need to wander around among the flocks of your companions when I am looking for you." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"goes all around"
"friends" or "co-workers"

tn.ref: follow the tracks of my flock
tn.text: "follow along behind the flock"
marks of the hooves of the flock on the ground
"graze your young goats" or "let your young goats eat"
The woman's lover continues speaking.
"the one whom I love"

tn.ref: to a mare among Pharaoh's chariot horses
tn.text: The lover compares the young woman to a beautiful female horse. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
"Pharaoh's horses that pull chariots"
"with spots of silver"
"sat at his table"
"gave off its good smell"
an oil that people got from the expensive nard or spikenard (valerian plant with small pink or white flowers) and used to make their skin soft to have a pleasant odor.

tn.ref: My beloved is to me like
tn.text: "For me, my beloved is like"

tn.ref: spends the night lying between my breasts
tn.text: "lies between my breasts all night long." Women put a small amount of expensive myrrh between their breasts to give them a continual pleasant odor. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
flowers from a small desert tree that people used as a perfume
The word "See" here adds emphasis to what follows. AT: "Indeed"
Doves are symbols of purity, innocence, gentleness and love. AT: "your eyes are gentle and lovely like the eyes of doves. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
The word "See" here adds emphasis to what follows. AT: "Indeed"
"good looking" or "lovely" or "beautiful"
plants that are green, moist, and grow abundantly
"are our bed." The woman describes how they lay on the lush plants outside as though they were their bed

tn.ref: The beams of our house are cedar tree branches
tn.text: The woman describes the forest as though it were their house. AT: "The branches of the cedar tree are like the beams of our house. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
large logs that support the rest of the house

tn.ref: and our rafters are fir branches
tn.text: "and fir branches are like our rafters"
pieces of wood that hold up the roof of a house
